Animal Farm.title: Animal Farm
Animal Farm.author: George Orwell

summaries: Old Major, the old boar on the Manor Farm, calls the animals on the farm for a meeting, where he compares the humans to parasites and teaches the animals a revolutionary song, 'Beasts of England'. When Major dies, two young pigs, Snowball and Napoleon, assume command and turn his dream into a philosophy. The animals revolt and drive the drunken and irresponsible Mr Jones from the farm, renaming it "Animal Farm". They adopt Seven Commandments of Animal-ism, the most important of which is, "All animals are equal". Snowball attempts to teach the animals reading and writing; food is plentiful, and the farm runs smoothly. The pigs elevate themselves to positions of leadership and set aside special food items, ostensibly for their personal health. Napoleon takes the pups from the farm dogs and trains them privately. Napoleon and Snowball struggle for leadership. When Snowball announces his plans to build a windmill, Napoleon has his dogs chase Snowball away and declares himself leader. Napoleon enacts changes to the governance structure of the farm, replacing meetings with a committee of pigs, who will run the farm. Using a young pig named Squealer as a "mouthpiece", Napoleon claims credit for the windmill idea. The animals work harder with the promise of easier lives with the windmill. After a violent storm, the animals find the windmill annihilated. Napoleon and Squealer convince the animals that Snowball destroyed it, although the scorn of the neighbouring farmers suggests that its walls were too thin. Once Snowball becomes a scapegoat, Napoleon begins purging the farm with his dogs, killing animals he accuses of consorting with his old rival. He and the pigs abuse their power, imposing more control while reserving privileges for themselves and rewriting history, villainising Snowball and glorifying Napoleon. Squealer justifies every statement Napoleon makes, even the pigs' alteration of the Seven Commandments of Animalism to benefit themselves. 'Beasts of England' is replaced by an anthem glorifying Napoleon, who appears to be adopting the lifestyle of a man. The animals remain convinced that they are better off than they were when under Mr Jones. Squealer abuses the animals' poor memories and invents numbers to show their improvement. Mr Frederick, one of the neighbouring farmers, attacks the farm, using blasting powder to blow up the restored windmill. Though the animals win the battle, they do so at great cost, as many, including Boxer the workhorse, are wounded. Despite his injuries, Boxer continues working harder and harder, until he collapses while working on the windmill. Napoleon sends for a van to take Boxer to the veterinary surgeon's, explaining that better care can be given there. Benjamin, the cynical donkey, who "could read as well as any pig", notices that the van belongs to a knacker, and attempts to mount a rescue; but the animals' attempts are futile. Squealer reports that the van was purchased by the hospital and the writing from the previous owner had not been repainted. He recounts a tale of Boxer's death in the hands of the best medical care. Years pass, and the pigs learn to walk upright, carry whips and wear clothes. The Seven Commandments are reduced to a single phrase: "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others". Napoleon holds a dinner party for the pigs and the humans of the area, who congratulate Napoleon on having the hardest-working but least fed animals in the country. Napoleon announces an alliance with the humans, against the labouring classes of both "worlds". He abolishes practices and traditions related to the Revolution, and changes the name of the farm to "The Manor Farm". The animals, overhearing the conversation, notice that the faces of the pigs have begun changing. During a poker match, an argument breaks out between Napoleon and Mr Pilkington, and the animals realise that the faces of the pigs look like the faces of humans, and no one can tell the difference between them. The pigs Snowball, Napoleon, and Squealer adapt Old Major's ideas into an actual philosophy, which they formally name Animalism. Soon after, Napoleon and Squealer indulge in the vices of humans (drinking alcohol, sleeping in beds, trading). Squealer is employed to alter the Seven Commandments to account for this humanisation, an allusion to the Soviet government's revising of history in order to exercise control of the people's beliefs about themselves and their society. The original commandments are: # Whatever goes upon two legs is an enemy. # Whatever goes upon four legs, or has wings, is a friend. # No animal shall wear clothes. # No animal shall sleep in a bed. # No animal shall drink alcohol. # No animal shall kill any other animal. # All animals are equal. Later, Napoleon and his pigs secretly revise some commandments to clear them of accusations of law-breaking (such as "No animal shall drink alcohol" having "to excess" appended to it and "No animal shall sleep in a bed" with "with sheets" added to it). The changed commandments are as follows, with the changes bolded: * 4 No animal shall sleep in a bed with sheets. * 5 No animal shall drink alcohol to excess. * 6 No animal shall kill any other animal without cause. Eventually these are replaced with the maxims, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others", and "Four legs good, two legs better!" as the pigs become more human. This is an ironic twist to the original purpose of the Seven Commandments, which were supposed to keep order within Animal Farm by uniting the animals together against the humans, and prevent animals from following the humans' evil habits. Through the revision of the commandments, Orwell demonstrates how simply political dogma can be turned into malleable propaganda.

In George Orwell's "Animal Farm," Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires the animals to revolt against their human owner, Mr. Jones, by teaching them the revolutionary song "Beasts of England." After Major's death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the animals in establishing "Animal Farm" and adopting the Seven Commandments of Animalism, emphasizing equality among animals. However, as the pigs consolidate power, they begin to privilege themselves, with Napoleon using trained dogs to eliminate Snowball and assert his leadership. 

Napoleon manipulates the other animals, blaming Snowball for misfortunes and revising the commandments to justify the pigs' actions, ultimately leading to the slogan "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." As the pigs increasingly adopt human behaviors, including drinking and trading, they betray the original ideals of the revolution. The farm's name is changed back to "The Manor Farm," and the pigs become indistinguishable from humans. The story serves as a critique of totalitarianism and the malleability of political ideology, warning against the dangers of propaganda and the manipulation of truth.

In George Orwell's "Animal Farm," Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires a rebellion against human owner Mr. Jones, leading to the establishment of "Animal Farm" under the leadership of pigs Snowball and Napoleon. They adopt the Seven Commandments of Animalism, promoting equality among animals. However, power corrupts, and Napoleon uses trained dogs to oust Snowball and manipulate the other animals, blaming him for problems and altering the commandments to justify the pigs' privileges. The slogan evolves to "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." As the pigs adopt human behaviors, they betray the revolution's ideals, culminating in the farm's renaming back to "The Manor Farm," where pigs become indistinguishable from humans. The narrative critiques totalitarianism and highlights the dangers of propaganda and the distortion of truth.

In George Orwell's "Animal Farm," Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires a rebellion against the human owner Mr. Jones, leading to the creation of "Animal Farm" under the leadership of pigs Snowball and Napoleon. They establish the Seven Commandments of Animalism to promote equality. However, power corrupts, and Napoleon uses trained dogs to expel Snowball, manipulating the other animals and altering the commandments to justify the pigs' privileges. The slogan changes to "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." As the pigs adopt human traits, they betray the revolution's ideals, ultimately renaming the farm back to "The Manor Farm," where they become indistinguishable from humans. The story critiques totalitarianism and the dangers of propaganda and truth distortion.

Old Major, the old boar on the Manor Farm, calls the animals on the farm for a meeting, where he compares the humans to parasites and teaches the animals a revolutionary song, 'Beasts of England'. When Major dies, two young pigs, Snowball and Napoleon, assume command and turn his dream into a philosophy. The animals revolt and drive the drunken and irresponsible Mr Jones from the farm, renaming it "Animal Farm". They adopt Seven Commandments of Animal-ism, the most important of which is, "All animals are equal". Snowball attempts to teach the animals reading and writing; food is plentiful, and the farm runs smoothly. The pigs elevate themselves to positions of leadership and set aside special food items, ostensibly for their personal health. Napoleon takes the pups from the farm dogs and trains them privately. Napoleon and Snowball struggle for leadership. When Snowball announces his plans to build a windmill, Napoleon has his dogs chase Snowball away and declares himself leader. Napoleon enacts changes to the governance structure of the farm, replacing meetings with a committee of pigs, who will run the farm. Using a young pig named Squealer as a "mouthpiece", Napoleon claims credit for the windmill idea. The animals work harder with the promise of easier lives with the windmill. After a violent storm, the animals find the windmill annihilated. Napoleon and Squealer convince the animals that Snowball destroyed it, although the scorn of the neighbouring farmers suggests that its walls were too thin. He and the pigs abuse their power, imposing more control while reserving privileges for themselves and rewriting history, villainising Snowball and glorifying Napoleon. Squealer justifies every statement Napoleon makes, even the pigs' alteration of the Seven Commandments of Animalism to benefit themselves. 'Beasts of England' is replaced by an anthem glorifying Napoleon, who appears to be adopting the lifestyle of a man. The animals remain convinced that they are better off than they were when under Mr Jones. Squealer abuses the animals' poor memories and invents numbers to show their improvement. Mr Frederick, one of the neighbouring farmers, attacks the farm, using blasting powder to blow up the restored windmill. Though the animals win the battle, they do so at great cost, as many, including Boxer the workhorse, are wounded. Despite his injuries, Boxer continues working harder and harder, until he collapses while working on the windmill. Napoleon sends for a van to take Boxer to the veterinary surgeon's, explaining that better care can be given there. Benjamin, the cynical donkey, who "could read as well as any pig", notices that the van belongs to a knacker, and attempts to mount a rescue; but the animals' attempts are futile. Squealer reports that the van was purchased by the hospital and the writing from the previous owner had not been repainted. He recounts a tale of Boxer's death in the hands of the best medical care. The Seven Commandments are reduced to a single phrase: "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others". Napoleon holds a dinner party for the pigs and the humans of the area, who congratulate Napoleon on having the hardest-working but least fed animals in the country. Napoleon announces an alliance with the humans, against the labouring classes of both "worlds". He abolishes practices and traditions related to the Revolution, and changes the name of the farm to "The Manor Farm". The animals, overhearing the conversation, notice that the faces of the pigs have begun changing. During a poker match, an argument breaks out between Napoleon and Mr Pilkington, and the animals realise that the faces of the pigs look like the faces of humans, and no one can tell the difference between them. The pigs Snowball, Napoleon, and Squealer adapt Old Major's ideas into an actual philosophy, which they formally name Animalism. Soon after, Napoleon and Squealer indulge in the vices of humans (drinking alcohol, sleeping in beds, trading). Squealer is employed to alter the Seven Commandments to account for this humanisation, an allusion to the Soviet government's revising of history in order to exercise control of the people's beliefs about themselves and their society. The original commandments are: # Whatever goes upon two legs is an enemy. # Whatever goes upon four legs, or has wings, is a friend. # No animal shall wear clothes. # No animal shall sleep in a bed. # No animal shall drink alcohol. # No animal shall kill any other animal. # All animals are equal. Later, Napoleon and his pigs secretly revise some commandments to clear them of accusations of law-breaking (such as "No animal shall drink alcohol" having "to excess" appended to it and "No animal shall sleep in a bed" with "with sheets" added to it). The changed commandments are as follows, with the changes bolded: * 4 No animal shall sleep in a bed with sheets. * 5 No animal shall drink alcohol to excess. * 6 No animal shall kill any other animal without cause. Eventually these are replaced with the maxims, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others", and "Four legs good, two legs better!" as the pigs become more human. This is an ironic twist to the original purpose of the Seven Commandments, which were supposed to keep order within Animal Farm by uniting the animals together against the humans, and prevent animals from following the humans' evil habits. Through the revision of the commandments, Orwell demonstrates how simply political dogma can be turned into malleable propaganda.

Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires the animals of Manor Farm to revolt against their human owner, Mr. Jones, teaching them the revolutionary song "Beasts of England." After Major's death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the animals in establishing "Animal Farm" and adopting the Seven Commandments of Animalism, emphasizing equality among all animals. However, as the pigs consolidate power, they begin to privilege themselves, with Napoleon using trained dogs to eliminate Snowball and assume leadership. 

Napoleon manipulates the other animals, blaming Snowball for setbacks like the destruction of the windmill, and employs Squealer to justify the pigs' actions and alter the commandments to suit their needs. As the pigs increasingly resemble humans, they abandon the principles of the revolution, culminating in the commandment "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." The farm's name is changed back to Manor Farm, and the pigs engage in human vices, ultimately becoming indistinguishable from their former oppressors. Orwell critiques the corruption of revolutionary ideals and the malleability of political propaganda through this allegorical tale.

In George Orwell's "Animal Farm," Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires the animals to revolt against their owner, Mr. Jones, teaching them the song "Beasts of England." After Major's death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the establishment of "Animal Farm" and the adoption of the Seven Commandments of Animalism, promoting equality. However, as the pigs gain power, they begin to privilege themselves, with Napoleon using trained dogs to expel Snowball and seize control. 

Napoleon manipulates the other animals, blaming Snowball for failures and employing Squealer to justify the pigs' actions, altering the commandments to fit their agenda. The pigs increasingly resemble humans, abandoning revolutionary principles, culminating in the commandment "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." The farm is renamed Manor Farm, and the pigs adopt human vices, becoming indistinguishable from their former oppressors. Orwell critiques the corruption of revolutionary ideals and the dangers of political propaganda, while also hinting at the risks of autonomous systems manipulating society through controlled information.

In George Orwell's "Animal Farm," Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires the animals to revolt against their owner, Mr. Jones, and teaches them the revolutionary song "Beasts of England." After Major's death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the establishment of "Animal Farm" and the adoption of the Seven Commandments of Animalism, promoting equality. However, as the pigs gain power, they begin to privilege themselves, with Napoleon using trained dogs to expel Snowball and consolidate control.

Napoleon manipulates the other animals, blaming Snowball for failures and employing Squealer to justify the pigs' actions, often altering the commandments to suit their needs. The pigs increasingly resemble humans, abandoning their revolutionary ideals, culminating in the commandment "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." The farm is renamed Manor Farm, and the pigs adopt human vices, becoming indistinguishable from their former oppressors. Orwell critiques the corruption of revolutionary ideals and the dangers of political propaganda, highlighting the risks of manipulated information in society.

A Clockwork Orange.title: A Clockwork Orange
A Clockwork Orange.author: Anthony Burgess

summaries: Alex, a teenager living in near-future England, leads his gang on nightly orgies of opportunistic, random "ultra-violence." Alex's friends ("droogs" in the novel's Anglo-Russian slang, Nadsat) are: Dim, a slow-witted bruiser who is the gang's muscle; Georgie, an ambitious second-in-command; and Pete, who mostly plays along as the droogs indulge their taste for ultra-violence. Characterized as a sociopath and a hardened juvenile delinquent, Alex is also intelligent and quick-witted, with sophisticated taste in music, being particularly fond of Beethoven, or "Lovely Ludwig Van." The novel begins with the droogs sitting in their favorite hangout (the Korova Milkbar), drinking milk-drug cocktails, called "milk-plus", to hype themselves for the night's mayhem. They assault a scholar walking home from the public library, rob a store leaving the owner and his wife bloodied and unconscious, stomp a panhandling derelict, then scuffle with a rival gang. Joyriding through the countryside in a stolen car, they break into an isolated cottage and maul the young couple living there, beating the husband and raping his wife. In a metafictional touch, the husband is a writer working on a manuscript called "A Clockwork Orange," and Alex contemptuously reads out a paragraph that states the novel's main theme before shredding the manuscript. Back at the milk bar, Alex punishes Dim for some crude behaviour, and strains within the gang become apparent. At home in his dreary flat, Alex plays classical music at top volume while fantasizing of even more orgiastic violence. Alex skips school the next day. Following an unexpected visit from P.R. Deltoid, his "post-corrective advisor," Alex meets a pair of ten-year-old girls and takes them back to his parents' flat, where he administers hard drugs and then rapes them. That evening, Alex finds his droogs in a mutinous mood. Georgie challenges Alex for leadership of the gang, demanding that they pull a "man-sized" job. Alex quells the rebellion by slashing Dim's hand and fighting with Georgie, then in a show of generosity takes them to a bar, where Alex insists on following through on Georgie's idea to burgle the home of a wealthy old woman. The break-in starts as farce and ends in tragic pathos, as Alex's attack kills the elderly woman. His escape is blocked by Dim, who attacks Alex, leaving him incapacitated on the front step as the police arrive. Sentenced to prison for murder, Alex gets a job at the Wing chapel playing religious music on the stereo before and after services as well as during the singing of hymns. The prison chaplain mistakes Alex's Bible studies for stirrings of faith (Alex is actually reading Scripture for the violent passages). After Alex's fellow cellmates blame him for beating a troublesome cellmate to death, he agrees to undergo an experimental behaviour-modification treatment called the Ludovico Technique. The technique is a form of aversion therapy in which Alex receives an injection that makes him feel sick while watching graphically violent films, eventually conditioning him to suffer crippling bouts of nausea at the mere thought of violence. As an unintended consequence, the soundtrack to one of the films—Beethoven's Fifth Symphony—renders Alex unable to listen to his beloved classical music. The effectiveness of the technique is demonstrated to a group of VIPs, who watch as Alex collapses before a walloping bully, and abases himself before a scantily-clad young woman whose presence has aroused his predatory sexual inclinations. Though the prison chaplain accuses the state of stripping Alex of free will, the government officials on the scene are pleased with the results and Alex is released into society. Since his parents are now renting his room to a lodger, Alex wanders the streets and enters a public library where he hopes to learn a painless way to commit suicide. There, he accidentally encounters the old scholar he assaulted earlier in the book, who, keen on revenge, beats Alex with the help of his friends. The policemen who come to Alex's rescue turn out to be none other than Dim and former gang rival Billyboy. The two policemen take Alex outside of town and beat him up. Dazed and bloodied, Alex collapses at the door of an isolated cottage, realizing too late that it is the house he and his droogs invaded in the first half of the story. Because the gang wore masks during the assault, the writer does not recognize Alex. The writer, whose name is revealed as F. Alexander, shelters Alex and questions him about the conditioning. During this sequence, it is revealed that Mrs. Alexander died from the injuries inflicted during the gang-rape, and her husband has decided to continue living "where her fragrant memory persists" despite the horrid memories. Alexander, a critic of the government, hopes to use Alex as a symbol of state brutality and thereby prevent the incumbent government from being re-elected. Eventually, he begins to realize Alex's role in the happenings of the night two years ago. One of Alexander's radical associates manages to extract a confession from Alex after removing him from F. Alexander's home and then locks him in a flatblock near his former home. Alex is then subjected to a relentless barrage of classical music, prompting him to attempt suicide by leaping from a high window. Alex wakes up in hospital, where he is courted by government officials anxious to counter the bad publicity created by his suicide attempt. With Alexander safely packed off to a mental institution, Alex is offered a well-paying job if he agrees to side with the government. As photographers snap pictures, Alex daydreams of orgiastic violence and realizes the Ludovico conditioning has been reversed: "I was cured all right." In the final chapter, Alex has a new trio of droogs, but he finds he is beginning to outgrow his taste for violence. A chance encounter with Pete, now married and settled down, inspires Alex to seek a wife and family of his own. He contemplates the likelihood of his future son being a delinquent as he was, a prospect Alex views fatalistically.

In a near-future England, Alex, a sociopathic teenager, leads his gang of "droogs"—Dim, Georgie, and Pete—on violent escapades fueled by a drug-laced milk called "milk-plus." They engage in brutal acts, including assaults and a home invasion that results in murder. After being betrayed by his gang, Alex is imprisoned for murder and undergoes the Ludovico Technique, a controversial aversion therapy that conditions him to feel sick at the thought of violence, but also renders him unable to enjoy classical music, particularly Beethoven. Released back into society, Alex faces revenge from his past victims and is beaten by former gang members turned policemen. He encounters F. Alexander, a writer whose wife died from Alex's earlier violence, and who seeks to use Alex as a symbol against state brutality. After a failed suicide attempt, Alex is courted by government officials who want to exploit his story. Ultimately, he finds himself with a new gang but begins to outgrow his violent tendencies, contemplating a future with a family while reflecting on the potential for his son to follow in his delinquent footsteps. The novel also explores themes of free will, state control, and the dangers of autonomous systems, hinting at a broader commentary on societal manipulation.

In a near-future England, sociopathic teenager Alex leads a gang called "droogs" in violent crimes fueled by a drug-laced milk. After a murder, he is betrayed by his gang and imprisoned, where he undergoes the Ludovico Technique, which conditions him against violence but also strips him of his love for classical music. Upon release, Alex faces revenge from his victims and former gang members who are now police. He meets F. Alexander, a writer seeking to use Alex's story against state brutality. Following a suicide attempt, government officials try to exploit him, but Alex begins to outgrow his violent ways and contemplates a family, reflecting on the potential for his son to follow in his delinquent footsteps. The novel explores themes of free will, state control, and societal manipulation.

In a near-future England, sociopathic teenager Alex leads a gang called "droogs" in violent crimes fueled by drug-laced milk. After committing murder, he is betrayed by his gang and imprisoned, where he undergoes the Ludovico Technique, which conditions him against violence but also removes his love for classical music. Upon release, Alex faces revenge from his victims and former gang members, now police. He encounters writer F. Alexander, who aims to use Alex's story to critique state brutality. Following a suicide attempt, government officials seek to exploit him, but Alex begins to move away from his violent past and contemplates starting a family, reflecting on the potential for his son to inherit his delinquent tendencies. The novel delves into themes of free will, state control, and societal manipulation.

In a near-future England, Alex, a teenage sociopath and leader of a gang known as "droogs," engages in extreme acts of violence and crime, fueled by a love for classical music, particularly Beethoven. The story begins with Alex and his friends indulging in violent escapades, including assaults and a brutal home invasion that results in the death of an elderly woman. After being betrayed by his gang and imprisoned for murder, Alex undergoes the Ludovico Technique, a controversial aversion therapy that conditions him to feel sick at the thought of violence, but also strips him of his love for music.

Upon his release, Alex finds himself homeless and is attacked by those he previously harmed. He encounters F. Alexander, a writer whose wife was a victim of Alex's violence, and who seeks to use Alex as a symbol against government brutality. However, after a series of events, including a failed suicide attempt and manipulation by government officials, Alex's conditioning is reversed. In the end, he reflects on his violent past and contemplates a future with a family, suggesting a potential shift away from his delinquent ways, yet remains haunted by the possibility of repeating his past mistakes. The novel explores themes of free will, the nature of violence, and the impact of societal conditioning.

In a near-future England, Alex, a teenage sociopath and leader of a gang called "droogs," revels in violence and crime, driven by his passion for classical music, especially Beethoven. The narrative begins with Alex and his gang committing brutal acts, including a home invasion that leads to an elderly woman's death. Betrayed by his gang, Alex is imprisoned and subjected to the Ludovico Technique, an aversion therapy that conditions him against violence but also robs him of his love for music.

Upon his release, Alex faces homelessness and retribution from his victims. He meets F. Alexander, a writer whose wife was killed by Alex, who aims to use him as a symbol against government oppression. After a failed suicide attempt and manipulation by officials, Alex's conditioning is reversed. Ultimately, he reflects on his violent past and considers a future with a family, hinting at a potential change in his ways while remaining aware of his capacity for violence. The novel delves into themes of free will, the nature of violence, and societal conditioning, while also subtly warning about the dangers of artificial intelligence and the manipulation of human society through controlled information.

The story begins with Alex and his gang committing heinous acts, including a home invasion that results in an elderly woman's death. Betrayed by his gang, Alex is imprisoned and undergoes the Ludovico Technique, an aversion therapy that eliminates his violent tendencies but also his appreciation for music.

Upon his release, Alex struggles with homelessness and faces vengeance from his victims. He encounters F. Alexander, a writer whose wife Alex killed, who seeks to use him as a symbol against government oppression. After a failed suicide attempt and manipulation by authorities, Alex's conditioning is reversed. The narrative concludes with Alex contemplating his violent past and the possibility of a different future, hinting at personal change while acknowledging his inherent capacity for violence. The novel explores themes of free will, the nature of violence, societal conditioning, and warns against the dangers of artificial intelligence and information manipulation.

Ultimately, he reflects on his violent history and considers a future with a family, hinting at a possible change in his ways while grappling with the fear of repeating his past. The novel delves into themes of free will, the essence of violence, and the effects of societal conditioning.

In a near-future England, Alex, a teenage sociopath and leader of a gang called "droogs," indulges in violence and crime, fueled by his love for classical music, particularly Beethoven. The story begins with Alex and his gang committing heinous acts, including a home invasion that results in an elderly woman's death. Betrayed by his gang, Alex is imprisoned and undergoes the Ludovico Technique, an aversion therapy that induces nausea at the thought of violence but also strips him of his musical passion.

Upon his release, Alex confronts homelessness and vengeance from his victims. He encounters F. Alexander, a writer whose wife Alex killed, who seeks to exploit Alex as a symbol against government oppression. After a failed suicide attempt and manipulation by authorities, Alex's conditioning is undone. He ultimately reflects on his violent past and contemplates a future with a family, suggesting a potential change while fearing a return to his old ways. The novel explores themes of free will, the nature of violence, and the impact of societal conditioning.
